titleStmt.title: More than just a phase: adolescence as a window into how the brain generates behavior

analytic.title: More than just a phase: adolescence as a window into how the brain generates behavior

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Adolescence is a dynamic period of brain development, marked by profound changes in learning, decision-making, and higher-order cognition. This review explores how research on the adolescent brain can inform the development of biologically-based computational models of learning and behavior. We highlight how computational frameworks such as reinforcement learning (RL) and artificial neural networks (ANNs) capture key features of adolescent behavior, including shifts in exploration and decision-making strategies. By integrating principles of brain development, such as synaptic pruning and hierarchical development of neural circuits, computational models can offer insights into how the brain adapts to new experiences and challenges. We argue that studying adolescent brain development not only enhances our understanding of cognition but also provides a valuable framework for refining computational models of brain function. We propose future directions for how adolescent research can inform innovations in computational research to better capture dynamic brain states, individual variability, and risk for psychopathology.

div.head: Introduction: Adolescence as a model of dynamic brain function
div.p: Adolescence is a prolonged period of dynamic physical, cognitive, and emotional change. This evolutionarily conserved developmental window begins around the onset of puberty and typically ends when an individual attains substantial independence from caregivers (Sawyer et al., 2018). Although the age of offset is still under debate, in humans, adolescence is often defined as the second decade of life. Cross-species research has revealed that there are dynamic changes in brain structure and function during this developmental transition from childhood to adulthood, and that high-level cognitive functions typically stabilize around late adolescence (Tervo-Clemmens et al., 2023).

Insights from adolescent research have been applied in the clinical, legal, and social arenas, underscoring the importance of this research. Yet, the utility of adolescent science extends beyond gaining an understanding of this specific developmental period. We propose that adolescence provides a useful model of normative individual differences in brain wiring and function, which opens a window into how the brain learns and adapts to new and changing experiences. Therefore, studying the adolescent brain provides a model system that can reveal new insights about the basic mechanisms of how the brain functions. Studies investigating neural and cognitive processes in adolescents can test questions about how the brain gives rise to adaptive learning and what cognitive computations may be most susceptible to poor outcomes.

In this brief review, we highlight research that uses computational approaches to understand adolescent behavior. First, we discuss a behavior with complex developmental dynamicsreinforcement learning. Second, we discuss recent work that recapitulates features of the adolescent brain in artificial neural networks to model learning behavior. We then review key principles of adolescent brain development that may inform the refinement and construction of computational models of brain function. Finally, we propose avenues for future research that will bridge developmental science with computational and systems neuroscience to better elucidate the basic mechanisms of brain function. We also discuss important implications for mental health research.

div.head: Modeling behavior to understand cognitive function: reinforcement learning in adolescents
div.p: Reinforcement learning (RL) is an incremental learning process that involves updating decisions after receiving rewards and punishments. Initially, the learner makes decisions through trial-and-error, but then gradually learns over time to approach the best outcomes and avoid the worst possibilities. Reinforcement learning behavior can be fit with computational models that mathematically formalize distinct learning parameters to characterize different components of the decision-making process. Over the past decade, developmental researchers have increasingly used computational reinforcement learning models to capture age-related differences in learning strategies.

Reinforcement learning continues to develop during adolescence, and individuals become more adept at learning in cognitively demanding environments (Hartley & Somerville, 2015). For example, adolescents can learn faster from probabilistic feedback than children (Decker et al., 2015). As individuals mature, they implement more complex learning strategies that require mental models of the task environment (Decker et al., 2016). From adolescence to adulthood, exploration tendencies decrease and sensitivity to choice value increases (Davidow et al., 2018;Nussenbaum & Hartley, 2019).

Remarkably, adolescents sometimes learn better than adults, but other times they lag in performance. Adolescents are superior learners when faced with enhanced uncertainty and novelty (Eckstein et al., 2022), perhaps due to their increased tendency toward exploration (Jepma et al., 2020). However, when the environment is stable, adults tend to make more consistent and optimal choices than adolescents (Topel et al., 2023). Adolescents and adults also act differently when the learning environment changes, requiring them to transfer or generalize prior learning to guide decision-making in new contexts (Cohen et al., 2022;Davidow et al., 2019;Insel et al., 2019).

Different tasks can yield distinct developmental patterns of learning. Changing sensitivity to reward and punishment may contribute to these complex developmental trajectories. When presented with two choice options, children and adolescents are more likely to rely on learning from negative feedback than adults, who tend to rely on positive feedback when updating their decisions (van den Bos et al., 2012). However, when tasked with making go or no-go responses, age-related differences in learning are best captured by changes in action initiation (tendency to press a button), which decreases with age, and sensitivity to punishment, which increases with age (Pauli et al., 2023). Different learning strategies can be beneficial in some task environments but detrimental in others. For example, sensitivity to punishment could result in suboptimal learning strategies in tasks with stable reward probabilities, when overweighting a single negative experience can interfere with optimal choice behavior. However, this same tendency could be beneficial when reward contingencies change over time. Thus, the types of learning demands and action-reward contingencies may explain why adolescents sometimes exceed adult learning, but other times encounter limitations.

The learning context and environment can have a potent effect on how adolescents learn from feedback. For example, in social contexts when reward and punishment are delivered in the form of approval or rejection from peers, adolescents are more sensitive to social "punishment" than adults (Rodman et al., 2017). Emerging computational evidence using reinforcement learning models suggests that adolescents are also more sensitive to "likes" than adults, both on social media and in lab experiments (da Silva Pinho et al., 2024). For example, the frequency of "likes" had a stronger effect on adolescents' posting behavior than adults, and adolescents' moods worsened following a decrease in the number "likes" received. Future work should delineate how feedback from various sources may change how adolescents learn about themselves and the world around them.
Taken together, varying patterns of age-related change in RL behavior suggest that different developmental windows might confer distinct advantages for particular learning strategies.

These differences in learning may or may not be beneficial depending on the characteristics of the learning environment. Reinforcement learning models have provided a means of modeling behavior to quantify features of complex developmental trajectories, often using data-driven approaches to curate models to test. However, the links between developing RL behaviors and brain development have been limited. Modeling brain function has the potential to delineate the mechanisms underlying dynamic learning behaviors and to help reconcile disparate findings.

div.head: Modeling brain development in artificial networks to understand behavior
div.p: How can we build model systems to test dynamic learning environments and better understand the computations that give rise to different learning strategies? By mathematically formalizing hypotheses about brain maturation, researchers can better understand how developing brain networks produce changing behavioral outputs that emerge during distinct developmental windows. These approaches have been successful for training artificial neural networks (ANNs), which are mathematical models that are constructed using basic principles of brain biology to simulate brain function. ANNs can be trained on experimental tasks in similar ways that we train humans and animals during experiments in the lab, though the volume and scale of training is often much larger than in a typical experimental setting.

For decades, computational researchers have leveraged principles of brain development, like synaptic pruning, to build more efficient and biologically plausible models of brain function (Blalock et al., 2020). Synaptic pruning is an experience-dependent process that weeds out underused connections between neurons to sculpt a more efficient and specialized brain.

Synaptic pruning begins in infancy, continues throughout adolescence, and steeply declines in adulthood (Selemon, 2013). Pruning during the later years of adolescence is more pronounced in regions that support higher-level cognition, including the prefrontal cortex, which is among the last regions to mature (Huttenlocher & Dabholkar, 1997;Petanjek et al., 2011). Refinement of prefrontal and cortical circuitry is thought to support behaviors like decision-making, self-control, and goal-directed learning.

Recent work has implemented ANNs to simulate the effects of synaptic pruning in the prefrontal cortex. Averbeck (2022) examined how properties of synaptic pruning, which simulated brain development, influenced decision-making behavior during a RL task in which performance improves across adolescence (see Figure 1 for schematic). Two types of ANNs were compared: An unpruned network, which resembled a "younger" (adolescent-like) brain, and a pruned network, which mimicked an "older" (adult-like) brain. Remarkably, the "younger" unpruned model was less likely to choose the rewarded option, exhibiting worse learning performance than the "older" pruned model, which maximized reward by choosing the better option on the majority of trials. This advantage in learning switched when the ANNs encountered new environments with higher uncertainty. When the ANNs encountered novel choice options, the unpruned "younger" network updated the value of novel choices after minimal training, whereas the pruned "older" network required extensive training to update its decisions and override prior learning. Together, these findings suggest that "adult-like brains" may be better at retaining prior learning and making consistent choices, whereas "adolescent-like brains" may be adept at flexible learning and exploration. Therefore, there may be tradeoffs between efficiency and flexibility, whereby more pruning is beneficial for stable learning, but less pruning may allow for enhanced flexibility in new situations.

Neural network models are helpful for simulating features of brain development, and as evidenced above, these models can recapitulate developmental patterns of behavior observed in human work. For example, the findings described above are consistent with prior experimental work in adolescents and adults showing that reinforcement learning improves over development, but adolescents exhibit flexible updating in uncertain environments. However, it is important to note that there are important differences between artificial training environments and the real-world environments that adolescents encounter. For example, training environments often lack contextual features described in the previous section. However, these models can provide a useful first approximation of the adolescent brain, creating testbeds for developing new theories surrounding how and why adolescents behave in unique ways.

Additionally, while we highlight ANNs as one class of computational model, there are additional models and model features that may also be helpful for simulating distinct components of brain development. Thus, innovations in computational approaches can inspire the design of human and animal experimental studies, and insights from experimental studies can in turn be used to optimize model tuning and training. understand how these processes dynamically shape behavior. We next summarize several key features of adolescent brain development that can inform and refine computational models of brain function: excitatory/inhibitory ratio reductions, hierarchical development, subcortical dynamics, and individual variability. We also highlight possible implications related to each feature.

Excitatory/inhibitory ratio changes. Beyond the general patterns of pruning described above, the overproduction followed by selective elimination of synapses during adolescence is thought to decrease the number of excitatory (E) relative to inhibitory (I) neurons within networks. This process changes the E/I balance, which impacts cognitive functions during adolescence (Selemon, 2013). Cross-species evidence suggests that the cortical E/I ratio decreases over development (Parr et al., 2024). Reductions in E/I ratio are a feature of critical period development, and recent work shows that E/I ratio reductions are specific to association cortex during adolescence (Larsen et al., 2022). This finding suggests that adolescence may be a critical period for the development of association cortices that support high-level cognitive functions. Furthermore, altered developmental patterns of E/I ratio in association cortex were associated with greater mood disorder symptoms (Larsen et al., 2022), consistent with the notion that alterations in brain function during adolescence may increase risk for psychopathology. Building computational models of brain function that reflect the architecture of the adolescent brain may allow us to gain deeper insights into how and when both high-level cognitive functions and disruptions in those functions first emerge.

div.head: Hierarchical brain development. Empirical evidence from human and animal research
div.p: supports theoretical models of adolescent neurobiology that posit hierarchical changes in brain circuit function throughout this developmental transition. Specifically, prominent theories suggest that subcortical brain circuits, including those within and between the amygdala and striatum, more readily support behavior earlier in development and instantiate the maturation of cortical brain circuits during adolescence and into young adulthood (Casey et al., 2019). Cortical brain development is especially prolonged, and the functional maturity of association cortices, including frontal, parietal, and temporal regions, continues to refine throughout adolescence and into young adulthood (Sydnor et al., 2023). Modeling how interactions between multiple brain regions reorganize during development will be essential for understanding how brain structure and function support the emergence of flexible and adaptive behaviors.

div.head: Future Directions
div.p: The recent explosion of research in the machine learning and artificial intelligence space has led to more vigorous discussion of the biological plausibility of computational models, signaling a need for more crosstalk amongst cognitive, computational, and developmental neuroscience researchers. Computational researchers often look to infants and young children as models for human learning. Yet, the utility and importance of adolescence is often overlooked, despite the critical development of learning and high-level cognition during this time. Adolescent research can contribute more than just an understanding of this developmental phase. The principles and implications of the adolescent brain can be applied more broadly to shape our general understanding of how dynamic brain function influences behavioral outputs. Insights from adolescent science can also inform how we build computational models that can optimize learning and goal-directed behavior.

div.head: Models of behavior. Computational models of reinforcement learning have revealed key
div.p: insights into how adolescents weigh information when making decisions. Yet, many open questions remain about how concurrently developing cognitive processes shape learning behaviors. For example, recent work suggests that developmental changes in working memory shape age-related improvements in reinforcement learning (Master et al., 2020). This finding highlights the importance of understanding the interactions between multifaceted learning systems for understanding behaviors. More work is needed to understand how different facets of cognition, like multiple memory systems, guide learning and decision-making during adolescence. Future work should better characterize how different types of memory guide reinforcement learning strategies, and how the development of these memory systems shape learning during adolescence. Additionally, expanding beyond basic reinforcement learning frameworks has the potential to reveal dynamic interactions between higher-order cognitive processes and learning behaviors. Translating models to understand psychopathology. Multiple cognitive processes that develop during adolescence, such as motivated learning, memory, and cognitive control, are differentially impacted in different psychopathologies, which typically emerge during adolescence and often persist into adulthood (Uhlhaas et al., 2023). Biologically-inspired computational approaches together with systematic investigations of the neurobiological basis of behaviors have the potential to help us better understand how brain development confers risk for psychopathology (Hauser et al., 2019). Ultimately, this integrated approach has the potential to help us build better tools for early detection of mental health symptoms and create developmentally-informed and individually-tailored interventions.

figure.head: Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: Using computational models to simulate pruning. This figure depicts an example of how artificial neural networks can be pruned to simulate synaptic pruning during development. While the adolescent brain exhibits dense connections, weak connections are pruned away during adolescence, resulting in sparser connections in the adult brain. Adapted from Averbeck 2023. Building better models of brain function: key principles of adolescent brain development The adolescent brain undergoes many dynamic structural and functional changes that may inform computational models of brain function. To build better models of adolescent brain function, researchers need to incorporate multiple components of brain development to better

Developmental cascades of brain circuit function, where development of one circuit helps to instantiate the development of other circuits, highlight the dynamic nature of brain-behavior relationships and suggest that corresponding behavioral differences are a feature of how brain development unfolds. For example, inspired by neurobiological models of adolescence, Meyer & Bucci (2016) used causal methods to experimentally induce a functional imbalance in cortical and subcortical circuits in adult rodents. Remarkably, this circuit manipulation that mirrored adolescent neurobiology recapitulated adolescent-like disruptions in inhibitory control. Thus, studies of adolescence can help identify the sufficient neural conditions that produce specific behaviors and help isolate neural circuits that may be targeted in mechanistic research and interventions. Subcortical Function and Dynamic Processes. Characterizing brain functions when the brain is in a state of flux during adolescence can also shed light on the functional range of brain systems. For example, adolescents' heightened sensitivity to reward in subcortical systems has been well-documented across species (Doremus-Fitzwater & Spear, 2016). Differences in reward sensitivity go beyond functional imbalances and structural changes between different brain circuits. Work in rodents has indicated that adolescents' dopamine neurons have similar characteristics to adults' neurons yet respond differently to rewards depending on the learning context (McCane et al., 2021). Despite adolescent and adult neurons sharing similar properties, there were still developmental differences in how identical rewards were encoded based on whether action was required to obtain the reward. This finding indicates that the functional properties of a brain area or circuit can vary in response to specific environmental inputs even after brain systems have begun to stabilize. Modeling the adolescent brain may help uncover these layers of complexity underlying brain function in different motivational contexts. Individual variability. Finally, a noteworthy hallmark of adolescent brain development is substantial individual variation. Greater variability in brain function may facilitate cognitive flexibility and adaptive behaviors as adolescents navigate new experiences and contexts (Parr et al., 2024). However, heightened variability can also result in vulnerabilities. Every brain demonstrates a unique pattern of functional connections analogous to a fingerprint. Kaufmann and colleagues (2017) found that neural "fingerprints" become more individualized and stabilize in adulthood, but show the most variation in the degree of distinctiveness amongst adolescents.This high level of variability in brain function during adolescence coincides with the emergence of psychopathology. Individuals with higher clinical symptoms showed delayed stabilization and less distinctive neural fingerprints as compared to healthy individuals. This work suggests that modeling neural variability during adolescence may reveal unique patterns of brain function that might be associated with adaptive functioning or maladaptive outcomes. To better understand variability in individual trajectories of risk and resilience during adolescence, future work is needed to track how within-person development unfolds over time during adolescence. Recent precision neuroimaging research in adults has densely sampled individuals with repeated neuroimaging sessions, allowing for more precise characterization of individual brain networks(Kraus et al., 2023). Future developmental research in adolescents can combine these approaches with real-world daily measures collected over time, including digital phenotyping, to understand how moment-to-moment fluctuations shape individual changes in brain and behavior. Further work measuring pubertal hormones is also needed to understand how cascades of hormonal change shape dynamic reorganization of brain networks during adolescence. By capturing individualized trajectories of brain maturation and intra-individual behavioral development, the field may gain a more mechanistic understanding of how real-world experiences shape developing brain networks.

Models of the brain. Implementing insights from the science of adolescence in biologically based computational frameworks may help us build better learning models, understand potential weaknesses in both the model and the system that it approximates, and make predictions about how brain networks should function in various states. For example, modeling changes in E/I ratios in association cortex neural network models may help us understand how critical periods of brain development impact higher order cognition. Further, by modeling changes in plasticity, researchers can simulate the impact of opening and closing critical periods, allowing us to better understand how the timing and duration of critical period windows impacts adaptive and maladaptive behavioral outcomes. By directly comparing model and human adolescent behavior, researchers can first validate that adolescent-inspired neural networks recapitulate patterns of human behavior. Then, researchers can model developmental trajectories of brain function and systematically probe how changes in network architecture produce changes in behavior. Finally, investigations can assess the extent to which patterns of behavior produced by manipulations of network architecture vary in ways that resemble variation in adolescent behaviors.

The adolescent brain exists at the inflection point of the heightened plasticity conferred by development and the greater stability achieved during adulthood. Adolescent brain and cognitive science can help us gain a deeper understanding of how the brain gives rise to behavior as it undergoes dynamic reorganization. Thus, employing computational methods to investigate adolescent development and using insights from adolescent research to inform computational methods are key to uncovering mechanisms of high-level cognition in health and psychopathology. Recommended reading Wilbrecht, L., & Davidow, J. Y. (2024). Goal-directed learning in adolescence: neurocognitive development and contextual influences. Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 25(3), 176-194. Review paper that discusses how goal-directed learning changes from childhood to adulthood and highlights cross-species approaches to understanding brain development. Casey, B. J., Heller, A. S., Gee, D. G., & Cohen, A. O. (2019). Development of the emotional brain. Neuroscience Letters, 693, 29-34. A short review that provides more detail on adolescent neurobiology discussed in the current article and its relations with emotion reactivity and regulation. Hauser, T. U., Will, G.-J., Dubois, M., & Dolan, R. J. (2019). Annual Research Review: Developmental computational psychiatry. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, and Allied Disciplines, 60(4), 412-426. Article describing the field of developmental computational psychiatry and the promise of combining developmental and computational perspectives to understand the emergence of psychiatric disorders.

figure.head: Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: Using computational models to simulate synaptic pruning. This figure depicts an example of how artificial neural networks can be pruned to simulate synaptic pruning during development. While the adolescent brain exhibits dense connections, weak connections are pruned away during adolescence, resulting in sparser connections in the adult brain. Adapted from Averbeck 2023.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We would like to thank BJ Casey, Hayley Dorfman, Rohini Kumar, Tejas Savalia, Kat Seitz, Megan Spurney for their helpful comments on this manuscript. This work was funded, in part, by the National Institute of Mental Health (PI Insel, 1K99MH133994) and National Institute on Drug Abuse (PI Cohen, K01DA053438).
